thread.title: This time, No. 3 Garrison Forest holds on, beats No. 2 McDonogh
thread.title_full: This time, No. 3 Garrison Forest holds on, beats No. 2 McDonogh

author: Rich Scherr
title: This time, No. 3 Garrison Forest holds on, beats No. 2 McDonogh
text:
This time, No. 3 Garrison Forest holds on, beats No. 2 McDonogh (#{text}) Rich Scherr For The Baltimore Sun Garrison Forest scored three goals in the first 10 minutes, 38 seconds against McDonogh. 
Battling for supremacy in the always-brutal Interscholastic Athletic Association of Maryland A Conference, No. 3 Garrison Forest simply couldn't afford another misstep. 
On a warm Wednesday afternoon in Owings Mills, the visiting Grizzlies instead stepped up to the challenge of No. 2 McDonogh. 
In a rematch of last year's conference championship, Garrison Forest scored three goals in the first 10 minutes, 38 seconds, then held off the Eagles' second-half surge to preserve a 3-2 win. 
Exactly one week after surrendering a two-goal lead in a loss to top-ranked Archbishop Spalding, the Grizzlies were intent to not let history repeat. 
"We came out really strong against Spalding and then kind of fizzled out, and it was beginning to look like the same kind of thing," Garrison Forest coach Traci Davis said. "We were pretty bummed about losing [that game]. … These are particularly big games for seeding, and the girls knew that. They came to play." 
Down the stretch, however, it was the top-ranked Cavaliers who left nothing to chance. ... ... (Rich Scherr) 
The win allowed Garrison Forest (10-1-1 overall, 3-1 conference) to remain within a game of A Conference-leader Spalding with two weeks left in the regular season. Both the Grizzlies and Eagles (9-2, 4-2) have lost to the Cavaliers by identical 3-2 scores. 
In this one, Garrison Forest seemed intent to put away McDonogh early. 
The Grizzlies took the lead on a goal by junior Ali Baratta just 2:13 into the game and made it 2-0 two minutes later when senior Hailey Mules took a pass near midfield, sped past her defender and scored on a one-on-one in front of the goal. 
When junior Natalie Adamez then scored off a corner from Mules with 19:22 left in the half, the lead had ballooned to 3-0, and could've been more if not for a missed penalty stroke. 
In Wednesday's season opener against top-ranked Severna Park, however, the host Eagles may have exceeded even the loftiest of expectations. ... ... (Rich Scherr) 
But this game was far from over. 
After coming close several times, the Eagles finally got on the scoreboard midway through the second half on a goal from junior D'Arcy Carlson, then cut the lead to one when senior Brindi Griffin scored off a feed from Allie Weiner with 11:10 to play. 
Quickly, the similarities to last week's blown lead became apparent to players. 
"That was definitely going through my head a little bit," Mules said. "All I could think was, 'They're coming back,' and we were doing the same thing as last time. I think we just had to punch through and try really hard to bring out all the things we practiced. We were really pumped to win." 
Still, McDonogh controlled the ball for much of the second half, missing out on several chances to tie, including six penalty corners. 
"It was just a slow start. After that … I honestly feel that we, skill-wise, dominated the rest of the game," McDonogh coach Jonna Wahle said. "We just couldn't finish enough." 
On this day, Garrison Forest managed to avert disaster, but Davis said her team will have to learn how to play a 60-minute game if it expects to compete for a title. 
"We have to play two complete halves," Davis said. "All of these A Conference teams … nobody's going to give up. It doesn't matter if you're 5-0. Teams in this conference are so darn good … that a three-goal lead, a two-goal lead, it's not enough." 
For McDonogh, thoughts of a possible postseason rematch already are front and center. 
"I know we'll see them again [in the playoffs]," Wahle said. "I'm planning on it." 
Field Hockey 
Garrison Forest 3, McDonogh 2 
Goals: GF-Baratta, Mules, Adamez; M-Carlson, Griffin. Assists: GF-Frazier, Mules; M-Weiner. Saves: GF-Evarts 8, Riley 5; M-Hyatt 7. Half: Garrison Forest, 3-0.
